#Text=2. Principles of Resolver-to-Digital Conversion

#Text=In this section we first introduce the basic principle of the resolver and its subsequent demodulation methods , and then several previous RDC solutions are presented and evaluated for their advantages and drawbacks .
#Text=2.1 .
#Text=Principle of Resolver
#Text=A resolver is a position sensor comprising of a stator and a rotor , which is connected to the shaft of the motor for detecting its angular position .

#Text=The stator portion houses three windings , namely one excitation winding and two output windings ( sine and cosine windings ) , of which the voltage output amplitudes are orthogonally symmetric , specifically , sinusoidally and cosinusoidally related to the shaft angle .
#Text=The excitation winding is responsible for inducing voltage in the rotator windings through electromagnetic induction .
#Text=With the shaft angle changing , amplitudes of the two-phase voltages from sine and cosine output windings are measured and employed to determine relative position between the stator and rotor .
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=illustrates the configuration of a resolver and subsequent software-based RDC scheme , which serves as an integrated position estimation system .

#Text=The excitation windings are usually applied with a sinusoidal reference voltage of constant amplitude and high frequency , expressed as : ( 1 ) where A is the amplitude of the reference voltage and ω ref is the angular frequency .

#Text=When the rotor rotates , the output windings will generate amplitude-modulated pair signals as : ( 2 ) where K is the effective transformation ratio of the resolver and θ represents the angular position of the rotor with respect to the stator winding .
#Text=These two modulated signals u 1( θ , t ) and u 2( θ , t ) have the form of sinusoidal and cosinusoidal envelopes .
#Text=Then , envelope detection is necessary to obtain the needed signal .

#Text=In practice , there are always disturbances from imperfect characteristics , namely the amplitude imbalances , DC offsets and imperfect quadrature , which arise from eccentric rotor , unequal winding and non-orthogonal symmetry of the windings .
#Text=Hence , the signal after envelope detection can be expressed in the form : ( 3 ) where and are the offsets , and represents the imperfect quadrature .

#Text=Preprocessing methods ( noise reduction , calibration and correction ) are carried out to result in : ( 4 ) where u sin and u cos are two ortho-symmetric signals , whose trigonometric features aid in subsequent demodulation .

#Text=Finally , the angular position θ and velocity are calculated through suitable demodulation algorithms ( for example , phase-locked loop and arctangent algorithms ) to obtain the estimation speed and position .

#Text=As is demonstrated in the resolver ’s principle , the orthogonal symmetry of alignment of two output windings results in the orthogonal symmetry of both envelope signals and post-envelope-detection signals .
#Text=2.2 .
#Text=Classical Resolver-to-Digital Conversion
#Text=Arctangent Method
#Text=A straightforward method is to obtain the angular position θ is through arctangent operation of u sin and u cos , given by : ( 5 )
#Text=As is clearly indicated by Equation ( 5 ) , the arctangent method suffers from its highly nonlinear arctangent operation and is limited to application on low-speed estimation .
#Text=Also , with a nonlinear feature , there needs to be a look-up table for the arctangent calculation , which increases the software loads .
#Text=Conventional PLL-Based ATO
#Text=As shown in
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=, the conventional ATO method tracks angular position based on PLL technique .
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=a is the actual form of the ATO , where kI and kP are the coefficients for the integral and proportional terms , respectively , and
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=b shows the linearized structure .
#Text=The estimated angular position is transformed through trigonometric function and multiplied by the demodulated signals .
#Text=By utilizing the feature of orthogonal symmetry in the resolver signals in Equation ( 4 ) , the phase error can be derived from the phase detector ( PD ) , expressed as : ( 6 )
#Text=When the ATO functions properly , the position error is small enough , that is , , so the input error signal can be expressed as .
#Text=Therefore , linearization of the ATO can be implemented , as shown in
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=b , and the closed loop transfer function is derived as : ( 7 )
#Text=The conventional ATO is a representative closed-loop estimation system which overcomes noise and track the input signal with a relatively high precision .
#Text=The linearized structure of the ATO belongs to a type-II system .
#Text=Compensated Type-III ATO

#Text=In , an acceleration-compensated ATO was proposed by employing the estimated speed to generate a compensation module for the position error , comprising a differentiator and a first-order low-pass filter , which finally makes this ATO a type-III system .
#Text=The actual scheme of this method is shown in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=and a linearized structure of this ATO is analogous to
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=b. Compared with
#Text=Figure 2
#Text=, there is a third parameter T representing the time constant of the low-pass filter .
#Text=The linearized closed-loop transfer function can be denoted as : ( 8 )

#Text=This compensated type-III ATO has the basic structure inherited from the conventional ATO but resolves the steady-error of estimating constant acceleration signal ( θ = α t 2 ) with a time-saving and simple technique of adding a compensation module , which achieves a higher precision in tracking the position of an accelerating motor .
#Text=However , this method fails to eliminate steady-state error resulting from a first- or higher-order acceleration signal .
